segments.text: the 25th of February.
23rd.
I'm 23rd.
I'm sitting in room 361 of the Hal Booty building with Tony Ganji.
Tony, try your mic.
I'm going to try it.
Is it working?
Tony, to introduce you to anyone who may read the transcript of this or hear this tape in years after this, describe your background and experience before you came to A&M.
Where did you grow up?
Where did you go to school?
Where had you taught and so forth?
OK, I was born and raised in Newark, New Jersey.
Went through high school at Newark, New Jersey.
That was in 1946 I graduated.
Went into the Army, mostly to get the GI Bill, which I got.
And when I got out of the service in 1948, the folks had moved to California, Southern California.
And so I went to UCLA using my GI Bill and started off as an electrical engineering major.
And because of the rigidity there was in selecting classes for electrical engineering majors at that time, I decided being an electrical engineer was not what I wanted to do.
So I went over to the physics department and became a physics major.
And when I got my degree after more than the four years, because I was working all the time, as well as the GI Bill, I was working all the time to work my way through college.
And so I ended up graduating with 165 credit hours rather than the usual 120.
But nevertheless, when I graduated, Ken McKenzie of the physics department invited me to be a teaching assistant.
And I took him up on it, became a graduate teaching assistant, and finished getting a master's and PhD at UCLA.
Officially got the PhD in 1960.
I officially graduated with a bachelor's degree from UCLA in 1952, got the master's degree in 1953, and officially the PhD in 1960, although I had finished up in 1959.
It was a question of writing the dissertation and getting it approved.
I went to work for
Space General, or it was Space Electronics, it was called at that time.
It was a company run by Jim Fletcher, who later became the president of the University of Utah, and Frank Leehan, who later became Secretary of Transportation in Johnson's administration.
And we worked on weapons systems, communications, self-focusing antenna arrays, underground communication,
side-looking radar, synthetic aperture radar, and a lot of those things.
And I found it very interesting.
The only problem was I was always working on war machines.
And I figured I didn't spend all those years going to school to be working on war machines or things like that.
So I decided to leave and go back to the academia.
I was fortunate enough to get a position at MIT in their geology and geophysics department.
I spent three years there.
That was in 1964 through 67.
And got to meet some very fine people.
Ray Hyde, who is now at the British Meteorological Office.
I suppose he's retired by now.
Nafi Toxos, who's still at MIT.
And Frank Press became department head.
There were really a bunch of super people.
Ted Madden is another one who probably retired by now.
And anyway, in 67, I then came to A&M, and the geophysics department was just starting.
So I think I was the fourth member, or actually tied for third and fourth.
Dave Falk was the first geophysicist at that time.
There had been a geophysicist before then.
It was Pete Dellinger and Joe Berg were geophysicists in the early 60s or even in the 50s.
But they left and went to Oregon State.
And then Dave Falkwas came in 1962.
They started the College of Geoscience and brought in Horace Byers, I think, in 1966.
Terry Spencer came in as the head of geophysics.
So he and Dave Falkwas were...
the two members of the geophysics department.
And then in 1957, Bob Unterberger and I were both hired.

you said 57 oh yes 67 oh yes right right in 67. now actually i must admit that at the same time john handen came and john handen was sort of considered part of the uh geophysics as well as george sowers who was also part of the center for tectonal physics and he was part of geophysics and i believe john logan also so it was a time of rapid growth as far as you know
Whose idea was it that geophysics would get emphasized here and that there would be a real first rate program in geophysics?
I really don't know.

I think it was Horace Byers or Earl Cook had a big influence on it too, but I suspect that may have come on down either from higher up yet than Connolly or Lyndon Johnson or I doubt Rutter thought so because he just wasn't knowledgeable about geophysics.
But I think both Connolly and Johnson were

well enough aware of the oil industry to recognize that geophysics was important as well as geology because there's always been a very strong geology and petroleum engineering program at Texas A&M for a long time.
How did someone identify you?
Who was it and what were the recruiting techniques they used to attract you?
Well, the thing they'd used to track me was money.
They gave me a good salary.
Actually, no, that's a joke.
Who was the person that contacted me?
I think it might have been Earl Cook and Terry Spencer.
Do you have any idea who it was that recommended your name to them?
It might have been my thesis advisor, Leon Lopoff, and it might have been Freeman Gilbert from the University of California, San Diego.
But actually, I don't know.
There were a number of schools that I interviewed at that time.
I interviewed at Penn State and Oregon State and Utah also.
And I liked A&M best because it seemed like they had the best chance for growth.
Describe
your impression of A&M at that time?
Well, it was in pretty bad shape.
It clearly had a lot of room for growth.
When I came on in and first talked to Terry Spencer
John handed, they were in what's now called the Howe Booty building and it was undergoing renovation and so there were things being repaired all around us.
Air conditioning ducts were being put in and so it was really in a pretty bad state of repair.
But it was clear that there was a plan to do something about it.
It was in the process of being developed.
And so consequently, that impressed me.
And also the people, Earl Cook, John Hand, and Terry Spencer, they're all people who sort of really felt like, and also Horace Byers, who felt like the geophysics was important.
And they wanted the geophysics program to be an important program.
And I felt like I contributed something, and so I came.
Describe those three men buyers cook and Spencer describe them at that time.
What were their responsibilities and their background.
Okay.
Byers was the dean of the College of Geosciences.
He was, I forgot, he came from Chicago or someplace like that, but I really wasn't sure.
And he was a very quiet person, but at the same time a very dynamic and strong person.
He had his own opinions, and he was very firm about his opinions.
He also had some very good ideas, but it was not a real, it didn't,
appear to be a pusher although he was certainly a guy who could do things and got things done.
Earl Cook on the other hand was much more dynamic guy.
He was interested in many different things.
He liked to talk and talked very well, carried on an excellent conversation.
He was a geologist and geographer and so he was really sort of a natural philosopher type more than anything else.
Terry Spencer
On the other hand, he was also a very quiet guy.
He was department head?
Oh, yes, right.
Earl Cook was the associate dean, I believe.
Terry Spencer was the department head.
That's correct.
And he had come from Chevron.
And before that, Chevron Research in La Habra.
And before that, he had been at Caltech.
He got his degree from Caltech under Hewitt Dix, who was one of the very famous guys in geophysics from Caltech.
Terry had done some nice work at that time.
He was a very quiet, very nice, very pleasant guy.
I also felt that he was somebody who would get things done.
What promises were made to you when you were employed, when you were attracted here?
Well, actually, the promises that were made to me was that I would be able to work hard and do something.
And I was pretty clear that I had a free hand, that I was on the ground floor, so to speak.
There weren't a bunch of old faculty members around who were going to say, this is what you could do, this is what you couldn't do, and this is how we did it in the past.
We were starting from scratch.
There had been no geophysics department prior to that, so it was the beginning of the geophysics department.
I felt that it was a real growth opportunity.
It was a place where I could make some impact.
I thought the impact I would make was more than I actually did make, but nevertheless, the potential appeared to be there.
What salary did they, we're not going to talk money except on this, what salary was the beginning salary?
The beginning salary wasn't too good as I recall.
It was I think about $16,000 for the full year.
It was less than the guys from
from people who went to the Center for Tectonal Physics.
It was still less than what I had earned at Space General before I left Space General and went to MIT.
And when I left Space General and went to MIT, I took a 25% cut in salary to go there.
But money has never been the most important thing in my life anyway, so it was a wage in which I could live on.
It was certainly a valid salary.
Did they make any commitment about research funding?
Yes, they did, as a matter of fact.
And they gave me some research funds.
They gave me money to, well, actually, I guess it was more teaching research.
My teaching and my research have always been very closely related.
And I was given funds to set up a laboratory that I used in the teaching of the seismology course that I taught.
And so we went out and we bought some equipment
a digital oscilloscope and parts and various electronic parts.
I was pretty well versed in electronics, then still am for that matter.
The other thing they did is they gave me a small allotment of money to build a laser strain meter.
because I had built a laser strain meter at MIT, which I had set up and got working.
I did build a laser strain meter, but never really ever got it set up here at A&M because conditions never seemed to be right to do it.
But that was about it.
Now, from what you have said so far, it seems that the recruitment of the geophysics faculty were from the big league
institutions in geophysics?
Actually, they weren't.
Other than myself, who, well, see, Dave Falk was from Woods Hole, that's true, but Terry Spencer was from Chevron.
Now, if you say where they had graduated.
No, that's what I mean.
Oh, okay.
Yes, right.
And Bob Unterberger, too, for that matter, was from UCLA.
John Handen was from UCLA.
But Unterberger also was from Chevron, Chevron Research.
And Handen and his crew were from Shell down in Houston.
But, let's see, Mal Friedman got his Ph.D. at Rice.
Oh, you know about Mal Friedman, right?
He walked across the stage either immediately before me or immediately after me when we got our Ph.D.s.
I'll be darned.
That's fantastic.
Okay.
Because there was a joke made when they read off the titles of the dissertations.
Yes.
And since mine in history...

about the presbyterian church in the south during the civil war was fairly easy for anybody to understand right they said and thankfully his dissertation is entitled and when i got off the stage friedman kind of gouged me and teased me about it i see um you you uh you people had big league

institutional backgrounds and also it seems that there was a kind of a common thread of real-world research space and petroleum and or petroleum related did that seem to you to be the appropriate combination for this department at this institution
Yes, not only for this department or this institute, I think for any department or any institution, I think having some practical experience is tremendously valuable.
It gives you a chance to get away from academia and to maybe get yourself weaned a little bit so that you get a little more mature and start working on it.
Bob Berg, who was the head of the geology department, he was also in the oil industry for a good while before he became the head here, I think also in 1966 or something like that.
Describe, if you can, getting settled in and getting started that first semester on this new campus in this new town.
Oh, well, it wasn't too bad, actually.
I looked around.
There were quite a few houses available in town, some very nice ones.
I bought a nice house.
I think I paid $25,000 for it at the time.
A four-bedroom, two-story house, brand new.
My wife liked it very much.
She kept telling me I should have bought a much bigger house, and she was right.
I should have bought a bigger house.
I'm still living in that same house, by the way, over 30 years later.

and there were a number of houses that were available in the general area eventually ended up about two miles away from the school so that was pretty easy there were a lot of stuff going on has he not only in the Enchano Meadows where I bought but also Don Cain had been doing stuff in the Oaks over there off 29th Street there was
There wasn't as much activity going on in College Station as I recall.
It was mostly in Bryan, close to Rosemary and that Stillmeadow area there.
Getting settled into the university itself wasn't too bad.
And it wasn't too hard, either, because of the fact that the courses that I ended up teaching here were ones that I had already taught at MIT.
So I had a bunch of notes already.
So it wasn't like I had to spend a lot of time preparing a bunch of new notes.
But I've always spent time, however, working on the notes because the courses are never constant.
They're always in flux, and you're always doing something.
But I spent a good bit of time at that, and I kind of enjoyed it.
I got involved with the people at the Center for Tectonal Physics.
I thought that was very interesting because they were doing, again, practical work and doing experimental work as a theoretician type.
and electronics type, both, I kind of enjoyed what they were doing.

did can you share any stories recollections of what it was like for a youngster from New Jersey then California to learn how to get along in Texas surely there must have been some times when somebody didn't understand you accused you of being from somewhere else well the answer to that is I never did learn
No, I'm joking.
No, I never really had any serious problems about it.
The Texans are really very nice people.
They've always been very kind and they've always recognized that I was a Yankee and therefore they expected a certain kind of deviant behavior from me and a different kind of manners and style.
I don't think they ever really resented it.

They would let me know, however, that their behavior was a little different and should be a little different here, but they always did it by their example, never by telling me, hey, that's wrong, don't do it that way, but by the way in which they would behave.
I learned to really calm down a good bit more and be a little gentler and a little more Texan, and it's been a good thing for me in my life.
Did you ever have any goofs on mispronouncing the name of this county or some other town around here?
Not this county, but I've always had a problem with Mejia and Tyvola and which I now know you know but yeah those were always very interesting and
But I was kind of used to that a little bit, too, because I'd spent 17 years in California after I got out of high school, after I got out of the service.
And of course, it had the Spanish influence there.
So you had San Jose and Tijuana.
So it was not unreasonable to have things pronounced differently than which they were spelled.
Let's see.
either as a friend or in any other capacity attempt to give you guidance as to what some rules were at A&M, either written or unwritten?
No, I don't think so.
Well, the written rules, I was told about the written rules in that there was a policy and procedure manual.
I was expected to read it,
I found out most of the rules by the hard way, by butting my head up against it.

One of the things I really felt very bad about when I came here is that I had this research money to buy equipment with, and so I went on down to the purchasing department and said, this is the stuff I want to order.
And they said, well, you can't order that.
You have to go through the submitting procedure and so forth and so on.
And, of course, it was really kind of hard for me to understand.
It was made clear to me that this was to prevent dishonesty or something.
I think that's what it went.

And I got very resentful about that because I thought I lived in the United States where you were innocent until proven guilty, but apparently as far as financial disbursements are concerned, you're guilty until you're proven innocent.
That took a little while to learn how to do that, but eventually I learned, yeah.
Now, how did the department operate in terms of decision making in those early years?
It was mostly the department decisions were made in the meetings, as far as I can tell.
I don't know.
what went on when I wasn't there.

But in the meetings, we sat around and we talked about what the courses should be, what the curriculum should be, how we should go about recruiting students, and what kind of students we wanted, and so forth and so on.
We had one of the very first programs of active student recruitment, I think, at Texas A&M.
where we sent out a bunch of letters to national merit or SAT score people, and we offered them scholarships to those who had done well in the science part of it.

And we had a large number of excellent students, because for one thing, we could give them a very small scholarship, and that would make them eligible for in-state tuition, which was a big difference in the tuition.
And most of these kids have found that most of the students who are just graduating from high school didn't know what they wanted to do.
And so if anybody showed any interest whatsoever in them,
about saying, hey, you've got a talent for doing such and such.
Why don't you try doing that?
We did that.
So we had this very strong program.
We ended up with really some of the best students on campus in the geophysics department.
They were so good that everybody was trying to steal them from us.
And they did very successfully, which was all right.
We didn't really mind.
But we had a bunch of good ones.
So most of the decisions were made in the department meetings, and they were mostly decisions about academic matters, you know, courses.
The students here, how did they compare with the students you had known at other institutions in terms of quality?
Our undergraduates were very, very good.
I think they were probably as good as the ones that are at UCLA.
The graduate students weren't quite as good.
However, I will say that the best graduate students we had were every bit as good as the graduate students at MIT.
But at MIT, they were all tremendous.
Whereas here, the best ones were as good as that, and then they would tail off quite a bit.
The undergraduates were, we had a good strong bunch in there because of this recruiting program and it was surprisingly because of the
the scholarship thing and the tuition waiver for out-of-state.
A lot of them were from out-of-state.
A lot of the students were from out-of-state.
And so they were quite excellent.
Of course, we had some students from in-state that were excellent, too.
But really, I say overall, the better students came from out-of-state.
The source of that scholarship money, what was it?
The oil company.
We had set up a program.
We had talked about this in the department meeting.
It was my feeling, too.
Look, we're here in Texas.
And at that time, the oil industry was really
the big industry in Texas.
And we're geophysicists.
Well, if we don't cater to the oil industry or train our students to be able to get jobs in the oil industry, well, we're just not meeting our obligation as a state university.
And that was an obligation that I felt.
And I think most of the other faculty agreed.
And we've always had a curriculum that was very applied geophysics oriented.
We have done some things in global geophysics.
But the major part of it has been in exploration geophysics, certainly at the undergraduate level and at the master's level.
When you get to the PhD level, why then the problems almost have to be more global than exploration.
So because of that, having very good students, and the oil companies were looking for good students, they would come and they would recruit.
And so whenever they came and recruited, we said, look it, you want good students?
We can get good students, but we need money.
Give us the money and we'll get good students.
You're not doing us any favors by giving us the money.
Well, they really were, of course, because we were getting better students.
I said, you know, because you're just making more work for us, right?
I said, but if you do that, why, then we'll have good quality students when you come here to recruit.
And they were very, very generous in that regard.
Are there some oil companies that deserve special mention that were more generous?
Yeah, let's see.
I believe Amoco was one of them that was really very active.
And Phillips Petroleum was also a good one.
And Shell was very helpful.
The others were also helpful, but not quite as much.
But those people were very, very active.
As a matter of fact, Gary Servos of Amoco would come and actually set up seismic chutes in the area for the students and things of that sort.
It was really tremendous.
In the late 60s and early 70s, for geosciences undergraduate students, what were the tough courses, either within the department or outside, that were kind of the gateway courses?

Well, for our students there weren't many tough courses in the first two years and part of the problem there was that we didn't have any geophysics courses in the first two years because they were all taking the chemistry, physics, and math that
We felt that a geophysicist, as well as geology.
We had some good, tough geology courses that they were teaching them.
And as a matter of fact, that was one thing that we had to do something about because we hardly got to see our students until they were juniors.
And by that time, they were being stolen away from us because all these other people had seen them and saw what great students they were.
They recruited them for their department.
So we set up some courses.
at the freshman level and the sophomore level,
for the geophysics majors.
They were solid courses, but we weren't trying to do any weeding.
We were trying to do some retention.
Actually, we never did any real weeding in trying to do that.
If there was any attrition, the attrition was natural by the chemistry, the physics, and the math courses, which are tough courses.
They would compete with the physicists, mathematicians, and the engineers.
Let's make believe you were an undergraduate advisor in that period.
What courses, if a student came in for advice, what freshman and sophomore courses did you look at most carefully to see how they had done?
Oh, I looked at their math and physics courses.
Math and physics.
Oh, yes, primarily.

And also their English course that they took as well, because that's one of the things that we found at that time, and it's still true, it's even more true now, is that the greatest training these kids needed was in communication.
And being geophysicists, they weren't really scientists in the pure scientist sense.
These were guys who were going to be applied scientists.
And as applied scientists, therefore, they had to communicate.

And furthermore, if they were going to go into the oil business, what they were supposed to do was work up a prospect and make a convincing story to management that this prospect was a good one, that they should drill it, and so forth and so on.
So communications was very important.
So very early in the game, we looked at their English grades.
In those early years, how adequate were the classrooms and laboratory facilities for teaching and research in geophysics?
The ones that were in our department were fine.
It was really not very difficult.
There weren't very many students, though, because at the peak, I think we had maybe 30 students in a class.
So it was always a small program.
And given that the program is that small, you've got 15 kids in a class, there's no way that you can do anything but a quality program.
You really would have to be a bad teacher not to do a good job with that few students, especially when they were very bright students, which is what they were.
What was the normal workload for you in terms of hours to teach per semester during those early years?
I generally taught two courses per semester.
And sometimes I would do three, but the third one would be a seminar or something like that, which really didn't take a lot of time and effort.
Later on, I taught more.
But the teaching load has always been very, very light in geophysics.
The idea was that we were supposed to, they expected us to do research.
They expected us to get research grants.
They expected us to have graduate students, because you supported the graduate students with research grants and so forth and so on.
And so there was that.
So the teaching load, I think, was quite light, my personal opinion.
And within the department, were good standards set in those early years for the faculty in terms of promotion and tenure and so forth?
Oh, I think so.
I remember I had to make a big deal and threaten to leave in order to get my promotion, but I got it.
I wasn't too old.
I think I was 40 years old or something like that.
So I guess if I hadn't threatened, I probably would have gotten it in the next year.
